reviewText:
Don't let the promising looks of it trick you. First off - its one of those mobile cash-model where you can just pay cash and end up owning all the best cards. Not even random - you have packages with 20 legendary cards guaranteed.

Then there would be the graphics - now im not someone to bash on the graphics because a game isnt running with 20158148 fps or has no 64x Anti-Aliasing, but this one is just an abomination. Final Fantasy 7 had better models.

Now to the gameplay - its sluggish. And by that i mean it takes forever to do anything. Every function, every button has some slight delay, some little animation even if there is no reason for it. It might not sound important, but it about doubles the time you would normally need, which means that it also doubles the time you will spend on anything doing in this game.

Also there are all sorts of creatures but only about 3 females, which have a massive cleavage but also the charisma of a tree log.

Anyways, looks like a quick cash-in. Cheap, boring, not worth your time. Dont let my sacrifice of playing it be in vain and just dont even bother with this game.
voteText: 103 of 155 people (66%) found this review helpful 7 people found this review funny

reviewText:
3.x Update Re-review SP Perspective
On release I quickly installed the game based on its cool sounding premise. Its half card game and half hex tactics game combined which sounded like a great idea. Played about half way through the first chapter and decided to pick up the Tripler and a few chests because I was enjoying it. Like many others who posted in the forums and gave negative reviews (including me), I hit a brick wall in my campaign a little later. In fact that brick wall would come down like a steel blast door at times if you didn't get any good cards. I hopped on over to the AI skirmish mode to find the AI got massive mana and starting hand bonuses that my pathetic cards just couldn't deal with. After multiple frustrating matches I simply gave up on it and left a negative review. At the time in the game's initial design, I felt that all I got for my money's worth was a frustrating experience.

Fast forward to the 3.1 update and I'd figure I would give the game another shot. I'm so happy to say that those initial bad experiences are over. Actually I've been bugging out on the game for the past couple days I'm now loving it. The single biggest change they made is that you can now obtain any cards you feel that you may need using gold coins which can be obtained for free by playing or buying with cash. You no longer have to depend on the RNG gods of getting decent cards from chests which could take a long while to obtain via skirmish on release. This changes everything because now if you got really crappy cards from your chests you got in the campaign before you hit that brick wall, you don't feel like your stuck in a catch-22. That is to say you don't have the cards needed to earn gold to obtain cards needed to progress. Now you can simply get the cards you need by going into the collection and picking them up that way. However now that you can play each chapter up to four times using the new formats as opposed to release when you could only play it once means that your chance of getting stuck in that situtaion in the first place goes down as well so that's another great addition.

The biggest challenge in the game from a SP perspective is that the levels are designed completely against the player in campaign outside the starting chapter and in skirmish the AI got huge bonuses (which have now also been reduced) to both mana income and starting hand. Add to that the AI had better cards than you on release amounted to a very frustrating experience. Now that I'm able to pick up the cards that I feel I need to overcome those challenges the game changes completely. Now that I'm able to obtain cards, primarily mass removal combos that deal with an AI that can swamp you based on its mana and card advantage, I don't feel like I'm at an impasse any longer.

Its turning out to be a really fun game given the changes. You'll also be pleasantly surprised at the amount of content packed into it given its a mobile port, certainly more depth to it than most other mobile games I've played. You have a TON of strategies at your disposal due to the huge number of spells and creature types you can mix and match. Very cool to see your card game come to life" where you control on a map the creatures you play.

Anyhow
date: if you’re thinking about trying the game for the first time it's worth checking out. If you're thinking about revisiting it then go ahead and give it another shot. The game really has changed completely for the better. At least this formally frustrated player thinks so. The Tripler in my opinion is one of the best bangs for your buck in any FTP game I can recall. Once you get it for a few dollars
recommended: it’s yours forever and not time based. A+ for that!!"

reviewText:
Awesome game.
It´s a mix of magic the gathering and chess, the mechanics are really good, the cards well balanced.
The developers are clearly interested in making a good game rather than a cash cow.
The prices for stuff is fair and you dont really need to buy anything, you get lots of free chests and cards and coin. i mean lots. you probably get way more than 50 dollars worth of free stuff throughout the campaign.
So it´s not pay to win, but i felt the game deserved some of my money so I got a 3x gold boost FOR LIFE for 5 bucks, and they even gave me the gold I had missed before buying the boost. with just this upgrade you can buy almost anything frm the game, because you can pick individual cards or chests and pay with in-game money..

Pros
- Free
-definetly not pay to win
-very adicitive and fun
-awesome game mechanics
-creative cards
-many different races and heroes
-well balanced races and cards
-begginer friendly, great tutorial
-cheap and rewarding microtransactions
-Really challenging but never frustrating


Neutral
Sound track, it´s ok
Graphics, ok too

Cons
I would just like to be able to see more information on the interface, like how many cards of each I have in my deck on deck builder screen (how many archers, mages, spells, equip etc) how many of each cost and so on, and be able to check used spells and dead monsters in a battle.
Oh, and the multiplayer chat needs improving, you can´t see older messages and theres a small maximum number of letters.
Just that, besides that it´s a perfect game.


Bottom Line is, this is my favorite game at the moment on steam and I´m sure the developers are going to keep releasing new content and perfecting the game even more. 10/10

reviewText:
I don't normally post reviews, but I tried this game for free, despite some of the negative comments, and have had a blast.

I've found the single player campaign refreshingly, and occasionally frustratingly, difficult. Every other level I've had to refine and tweak my deck and hope that my next card pack will fill the glaring holes that are bedevilling my strategy. That for me is where the fun is, but perhaps that's where the 'pay to win' comments are coming from. I honestly just think that the game is hard and perhaps people weren't expecting that with the cartoon werewolves capering about the screen.

I have now bought a tripler to help speed up my card collecting. I played for a good 15-20 hours before buying one though and given that I'm still enjoying the game I reckon £1.99 is a bargain, as I've paid far more for games in my library that I've played half as much.

reviewText:
Love this game, highly recommended!

After the recent update it became even better. And you don't have to spend money to play this game at high level. It's rare that the developers of a game are not after your money, and this is such a rare developer team. If you go to the forum, you'll notice that they're visiting the forum daily to communicate with and listen to players (many player suggestions are implemented into the game) and if you need support, you'll get a personal response very fast.

Anyway, if you like strategic games, definitely give this a try!

[Edited to add:]
If you're on the fence whether this is game is your cup of tea: the second video is actually quite good in explaining the game (you know, at the top of your screen there are 3 videos and then some screen shots). Like the voiceover in the video says: this game is like Magic the Gathering meeting Battle Chess.

[Update 4 June 2015:]
The game has just got a major overhaul, version 3, and it's now even better! More than 1,200 (yep, that's one thousand and two hundred) new cards. More types of battles (like a 'pauper deck' where you cannot use Legendary and Rare cards), more single player missions, and more free coins to be earned. Also the leader board is now reset monthly, and it's set up in a way that less experienced players can climb to the top as well.

reviewText:
An entertaining CCG with a lot of decent options for solo play, which sadly seems an afterthought in many of the other CCGs.

Since the latest major update not only have some 1200 cards been added but it sounds like they're even more generous with the free coins and chests.  I know every time I play, usually just a couple battles a session, I'm getting a few new packs (or chests as they're called in this game) to add to my collection either as direct rewards or bought with the cash I'd just earned (admittedly I do have the tripler in effect, which helps speed things up a lot).

Compared to other CCGs, the game is definitely on the lighter/streamlined side of things.  While it now has some 1900 cards now, and unlike Yugioh, they almost all have a point (albeit there are some really odd cards that clearly, outside of pretty elaborate combos, I can't see be included in most decks).  Another honest admission is that when it comes to the monsters themselves, the vast majority of the cards in this game, it can at times feel like they filled out the ranks by simply recombining some handful of variables in every possible configuration (12 races x 3 classes x 24 different powers x etc.) although, under closer inspection, it is clear there are some powers primarily available to certain races and definitely not seen in all 3 classes).

Another interesting aspect of this game is how simple they make it to buy or sell any of it's 1900 cards.  The basic rules that appear to govern this is that you can sell any card in your collection for roughly a fourth of its retail value which in turn is primarily based on its rarity (although there is a bit of supply and demand worked in as well, so expect to pay a little more than the straight rarity would indicate for a popular card and expect to get a bit less when selling a card there is no demand for).  If you're ever short on in-game cash just sell off those rarer cards you KNOW you'll never use.

Lastly I also like how the game structures things with its 2 most common chests, the mini and full.  Mini chests, 400 gold for 6 cards, are the cheapeast way to really add a lot of cards to your collection for minimal cash with the only downside being that the distribution of cards is totally random and 90% it will just be common cards with a couple of uncommon thrown in.  Full chests, 1200 gold for 12 cards, while a far more expensive route to go for your cards, at least GARUNTEES 3 uncommons and 1 rare (or better).  So, as it stands, I find myself going back and forth between both chest types, minis to fill out my collection variety, making sure I at least have a wide breadth of all of the game's common cards, but still throw in a few full packs to get my guaranteed rarer cards.

reviewText:
I'm just gonna stick to the point and list the Pros & Cons as i dont want to waste your time:
[1] Very Deep Strategy.
[2] Massive Solo Campagin (which u need to earn coins, and good cards).
[3] Easy to play difficult to master.
[4] More than 2,000 cards to choose from and build your deck.
[5] Make you always think (as the slightest mistake can bring you down easily).
[6] Absolutely not Pay to win (just boosters which you can purchase for real money to help you get coins faster).

Cons:
[1] Small Player Base (which i guess because of the poor marketing of the game).
[2] Not the best graphics (personaly i'd give it 7/10, but still its decent enough).
[3]You may need to spend money and get ''The Trippler'' (a booster worth 10$) or purchase some in-game coins if you want to finish the last couple of missions in the campagin (as its REALLY Tough and i mean it to finish if you dont have Strong cards).

Personally i think its the Best Free Online Card Game given its Small size, Deepness & Variety.

reviewText:
This came out before Hearth Stone and long before Scrolls. It has an extra level of depth than a digital CCG because of its board game layout. Terrain makes a huge difference in strategy and can reall determine the outcome of the match if you can force your oponent(s) from strategic tiles, envelope their archer heroes or pin them in a corner.

Online multiplayer is the best though and the more the merrier. The best online matches I have played were 2v2 and 3v3 with a mixture of friends/guildmates and strangers. The deck creativity you encounter is pretty awesome, especially when facing oponents using complimentary decks. I still remember a series of shattering defeats at the hands of another clan when they employed inferno decks, even though the night before we had proved better tatical usage winning 4/5 matches against them.

The animations are great, with moves, attacks and spells giving it a much more immersive feel than from 2/2.5D cards. Throughout the games short history, they have added a lot of new cards, balanced overpowered cards, strategies and heroes well.Recently they increased the rarity of rare and legendary cards, making it less likely to face off against an oponent using decks loaded with rare and legendaries.

reviewText:
The amount of hours I've sunk into this game... the Steam tally only tells 1/4 of the story, since it's also available on mobile. The Steam version is 100% compatible with the mobile versions: your cards and coins are stored on the server.
You can buy the tripler which triples all your winning bonuses for $5, and if you like these game even a little bit  you would be crazy not to.

The game is based around summoning monsters onto a hex grid to protect your hero and attack the opponents hero and monsters. There are various spells, runes and equipment to boost your hero and monsters.  Monsters (and heroes) come in 3 classes: warriors, mages and archers. Warriors generally have more attack power and damage based abilities, archers have lower attack power but can shoot 3 hexes, mages are somewhere in the middle and can attack within a 2 hex radius. Control-decks are possible, but generally you won't be able to win without monsters.

Prizes for completing missions in the single player campaign are generous. Prizes are also paid out for winning online games against human opponents and it's entirely possible to not spend a cent and own as many cards as the big spenders as long as you are willing to put in the time: every card can be obtained without spending money except for additional heroes. This makes suggestions that this game is play-to-win" simply laughable. Heroes have a system where there is a "hero of the week" which you can use for free
date: or you can purchase them outright if you decide you want one for keeps. You start the game with one permanent hero
recommended: which you can choose from a warrior
hoursPlayed: mage or archer.\n\nThe developers of this game are passionate about it
voteText: and it shows. They are regularly gathering feedback in the forums and implementing changes based on community feedback. If you experience a bug or technical issue they always respond quickly and have a fix ready in the next version."

reviewText:
Combat Monsters is a fairly complex card game with a lot of depth. The hex based movement on the board also makes it resemble a turn based strategy game.

There's a lot of variety in the the matches, thanks to the numerous features in the game. The game includes a lot of different boards, all of which have different shapes and feature several bonus tiles. There are also many different kinds of utility cards that you can use to strengthen your team and disrupt your opponents. All the different features work together well and give the game depth.

There's a ton of different cards in the game, although the developers tend to have gone for quantity over quality. A lot of the monsters are very similar to each other, and some of the spell cards require a very specific situation to be useful. I would've preferred a somewhat smaller pool of cards, with only cards that are genuinely useful and different from each other. Some monsters are so weak that they seem pretty pointless, since there are others that have the same usage cost, yet more health and attack.

The upside of the large card pool is that you have a ton of choice on what kind of deck you'd like to make. There are many different races and classes, all with their unique abilities. With all the variety available, it's fun to build new decks. You can make lots of different kinds of viable decks.

A few of the cards are a bit overly useful and fit in almost any deck, like the runes that allows you to draw extra cards every turn. This is a major advantage in practically any deck. Still, I haven't encountered anything that's clearly overpowered. The balance isn't perfect, but it's pretty good, especially considering the large amount of cards included.

These problems are mostly mitigated by how generous the game is in giving you cards. You can buy any card directly, which makes it easy to get the exact cards you want. The most popular cards cost quite a lot, but it does allow you to remove the luck element from getting the cards you want.

You get cards in the single player at a quick pace even if you don't pay any real money. You might have to replay the quests in other formats in order to get enough good cards for the hardest missions. The game is much more generous to free players than most digital card games.

If you do enjoy the game, you should buy the tripler. It triples all the cash payouts in the game. There's no time limit or any other catch to it, which makes it a great deal.

Some other reviewers complained about the game being pay to win because of how difficult the campaign is in some spots. The campaign does get hard later on, but not in a way that requires you to pay money. I finished all the campaigns with only 75% of the money an F2P player could get, so there definitely isn't a paywall in the game. As long as you're smart with your deck composition and don't rely solely on legendary cards to win, you can make great decks without paying money.

I really enjoyed that the single player offered a good challenge. It feels like a complete game by itself. In many other digital card games, the single player is more like an extremely easy tutorial for the multiplayer.

The presentation of the game isn't as strong as the gameplay is. Representing a card game with 3D models is an interesting idea. It makes the game much more animated and lively than usual. However, the art style doesn't match the game's content very well. The game's art style gives the impression of a simple, kiddy game, despite it being fairly complex. The recent update did improve the graphics somewhat. They're not AAA quality, but they look decent enough.

It's odd that the game has so few players in it, even though it's actually very well made and free to play. The player base does seem to be very dedicated to the game, so you can still find opponents for multiplayer games.

If you enjoy card games or turn based strategy games at all, give Combat Monsters a shot. It's a lot of fun.

reviewText:
I have to admit I have been very pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable this game turned out to be.  The game itself has a nice turn-based flow with a good range of abilities, and many potential paths to success.  There is a huge amount of single player content, with an extensive campaign that is replayable for rewards with 4 different deck style variants.  It is way deeper than you might expect at first glance, and I like it quite a bit.

There is one area of content that can't be acquired by normal free play - alternate heroes, and it does stand as a blemish on the otherwise good game.  Honestly, I'd say the whole pricing structure needs a hard rethink, since I don't think it is doing what it should be... encouraging you to pay a reasonable amount for the fairly significant amount of enjoyable time you are likely to experience playing this game.

That said, the heroes won't keep you from doing anything important.  So give it a play and have fun.

reviewText:
Now the first thing you're going to notice is that I've only played the game for .1 hours. Before you completely dismiss this review, let me explain why my opinion matters.

You see, I was just having a nice day when suddenly a friend of mine-let's call him Mr. D-messaged me to tell me to play Combat Monsters. Being the gullible idiot that I am, I downloaded it without question. While waiting, I watched a few episodes of Not Sword Art Online. By the time the ending rolled in, I have it in my library.

Right as it finished, Mr D messaged me to tell me to get on Combat Monsters. At the time, I felt like playing Dota, but I acquiesced to his request and launched Combat Monsters.

Now everyone say first impression is everything, and I agree. My face was concave from the impression this game gave me. The low quality 3d models, the mediocre soundtrack, the whatever UI, it all added to a feeling of nostalgia. I then said to Mr. D on skype, What the ♥♥♥♥ is this?" He chuckled
date: and told me to play the tutorial. Play the tutorial I did. What I am going to say next does not fully reflect on everything I feel. It is quite impossible to put this phantasmagoric experience into words. Nevertheless

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have played in quite a while! If you like turn-based board games and CCG, you really should try this game! Imagine playing chess but with cards that give your chess pieces weapons, armor, and shields! This game also incorporates runes which can be placed on the battle board via your card hand and spell cards which can alter your hero or monster’s abilities! This game is like chess on steroids, it has so much depth of strategy with all the combinations that it actually puts chess to shame! Many of the players that play this game have been playing it continually for over a year and a half, that says quite a bit about a game! And, if playing multiplayer type games is not your cup of tea, no worries, because this game has numerous ways to play single player too! The few Issues that I had with game were handled professionally and efficiently by a competent and small development team. Even though you can spend money to buy card packs, it is defiantly not a necessity to win or have fun! Give it a try and some time and have a blast!  And just to be straight I played this game mostly on the stand alone PC version, but it is the same game! ***** five stars*****

reviewText:
First of all I have played many trading card games and even was first generation MTG.  So I am very picky about card games in general and like most people that compare all MMORPG to WOW I compare all card games to MTG.  Also I have no affiliation with the DEVs or this company.  This game has a twist though.  The cards come to life and you can control them in a 3D arena, instead of static play and the popular 2D side to side animated versions.  The spawns are a bit cartoony, but at least they didn't go out of their way to make them all anime-like = cute & cuddly...  Has a Dungeon Defenders art feel to me with a bit more texture.  Even though the game froze a few times and loading a bit much for such a small game; I have had a blast.  The game only crashed once and it might have been the combination of FRAPS + Gameplay, since I am You Tubing the whole standard Campaign rounds 1-19.  Super easy! 21-0 so far!  Next will be 50 card campaign.  Only downfall is the online community is non-existent so you will be forced to play people that have been here all along to play.  Some say this is Pay-to-Win, but I feel as if it is more a Pay-to-Advance, but if your friend spends $10 he will have a huge advantage over you as new players until you learn the game, but even then still has some advantage.  Player skill varies so anything is possible!

"Opening this game to community allowed WORKSHOP creations would greatly boost this community!"

PROS

1. Fun factor
2. Easy to master
3. Nice Graphics
4. Nice Soundtrack
5. Customization
6. Themed Deck building
7. You can name & save many different Deck Builds
8. Pay top Advance Argument = Money can get you many nice cards that FTP people will after months
9. Has Potential
10. Endless possibilities for expansions
11. The various Tribes (Races) each have their very own unique racial traits/abilities
12. No player vs bot skirmish custom battles
13. Multiple accounts are allowed
14. All races have their equal (Or damn close) and their obvious conquering opposites.  Dwarves and Lizard men = Similar and Werewolves vs Dwarves
15. Great DEV response time and they care enough to reply to your reviews!!! (Just look in comments)

CONS

1. Limited Replay allowances
2. A bit too easy to master
3. Gold rewards do not feel rewarding enough for some stage completions
4. End Stage Card Rewards are the same for everyone
5. Some PvE, but ridiculous to make a career out of PvE only without a few bucks (Easy to tell)
6. Chest rewards seem a bit lacking, Mystery Chests minimum totals are a joke (Friend got 5 rubicoins as a reward and my lowest was 65)
7. The online community is all but dead -> (I AM CURRENTLY WORKING TO FIX THIS!)
8. Due to online opportunities lacking you need to play against experienced players as a new player (Could be good or Bad I guess)
9. Pay to Win Argument = Money in excess can get you all the cards you need instantly or at least save months of time gathering
10. Once campaigns are beat and the 4 allowed repeats are done = PvE is dead
11. Besides PvP no real replay value except for the eventual no EXP and no currency repeated rounds (ANSWERS = Map Maker and more campaign or allow endless repeating)
12. No difficulty settings
13. No Workshop
14. No player created custom map sharing (If Map Maker)


MISC (Neither Good nor Bad stuff)

1. No Map Maker
2. No real Co-Op (Because 6-player FFA alliances are not forced teams and easily backstabbed)
3. How about an ANTE system

All stated is as I experienced it and only one campaign is left out of the four within an 6-hour period.  I know some might have experienced something different, but keep in mind I am not you and so on... I breezed right through this game and in a few minutes the entire campaign(4) around 8 hours played.  The answer is more than obvious: Open game to WORKSHOP possible and add a Map Maker up to 6v6 instead of 1v1v1v1v1v1 or at least 5v5 so you can start tournaments and peek greater interest!


I had fun and will play again on my PvP practicing account"


Sirspoony Game Rating:  7.75/10 rated "GOOD"  10/6/15 UPDATED +0.5 due to DEV response

...with Map Maker = 8.25/10 rated "GREAT!"

...with infinite campaign rewards and More Campaigns and/or Workshop MODS = 8.5/10 rated "AMAZING!!"

...with online custom skirmish matches human vs Bots 1v1
voteText:
5v5 and 6v6 + allowed player made custom (Map Maker) matches = 9/10 rated "AWESOME!!!"

reviewText:
I have had a lot of fun with this game!

This game is perfect for me because:
-I can play it casually a little at a time
-It requires strategy and there is a virtually unlimited number of ways to put together a winning deck
-It's turn based (I like to take my time, maybe do something else while playing)
-It's free (sort of).  I started out playing for free but found I liked it enough to make some of the in game purchases

If you play, be sure to put in someone's gift code (preferably mine).  It will give you some extra cards to play with.

My gift code is QDDH9FE

Thanks for reading my review!

reviewText:
Very fun game.

You can get everything without paying money, just takes a little longer.

The single player campaign is really fun, and 100% NOT Pay2Win.  Multiplayer isn't necessarily Pay2Win, but you can definately tell who has paid(kind of).

As long as you build a smart deck, you will get along just fine without paying a single dollar.  I did buy the X3 multiplayer(2.99) that triples all the gold coins you earn FOREVER plus a few other things... Pretty sweet.

Since it is FREE to play, I definately recommend you try it out.

If you like Tactics or Card games, this is an AWESOME blend.  I don't really like card battle games that much, but this one doesnt feel like one.

9/10

I can't put it down, just bought it today

reviewText:
Saw this game on team and gave it a try and wow!!  Lots of fun, lots of strategy.  It looks simple but it's actually full of strategy.

Pros:  Build a custom deck of monsters, weapons, spells etc.
Lots of cards! Many options.
Fun graphics
Play online against other players!
Differnt battle maps, differnt startegys, endless fun.

Cons: Not alot of people online as this game needs more exposure and ads to get more players
Colors often too bright and can blind.  Muted colors would make it easier on the eyes.
They need colored bases so you can tell at a glace which monsters are yours.
Easier way to tell the difference in class and race.  I often summon an archer too close to use his bow.

Great game, and I'll be playing it here on out. I like CCG's and good strategy and this game delivers.

reviewText:
Combat Monsters is a turn based strategy game in which you build your deck from a bunch of cards.
You earn cards by playing campaign mode, player vs player, daily challenge and by buying / selling cards.
It's fairly reasonable to say you can get any card(s) you want if you decide to put some effort to it.

Gameplay feels smooth and graphics are ok, the only thing that really bothers with the graphics is that most units look pretty much exactly the same. Example all robot archers are pretty much the same in looks, but can have really big dif in stats and skills.

Othervise I love the idea that theres several races with their unique passive buffs and a very large pool of cards to choose from, even if you just started the game.

However, theres a few big issues with the game:

1. There clearly has never been any idea to keep cards balanced, you can have a unit that costs 3 with 1/8 stats and you can have the completely same unit, but with only 1 cost. The only dif is that the other card is legendary, the other is common. This is the basis why theres so many dif cards, theres a ton of cards that are just clearly a lot worse than another one. The only trick is that legendaries are expensive and you won't get a ton of those quickly.

Theres a few dif game modes you can play from which 1 doesn't allow any rare+ cards in deck. It's reasonable to say that it's the only gamemode you can have any chance in if you are starting this game. And even then you are facing the elite players.

2. Dead community. And I seriously mean dead. You log in, theres 2 guys online preying on newbies to smash.

Other minor issues are time to time graphics bugs and that the UI for building deck / going through your cards is just horrid. One could also argue that the whole UI is complete garbage. :)

This is one of those games that I kinda like, but I feel it's not worth playing the game since theres only 1 viable gamemode that is reasonable to play. I just don't see the point in grinding out weeks or even months to get the cards to compete in the 3 out of 4 game modes which all accept powerhouse cards.

I'v played a lot of TCGs in general and some of them on very high competive level, but I can't recall ever seeing so insanely big gap between your lowly common and most rare cards. It's like playing mtg so that you get 1 mana from each land and your opponent gets 3 and he has crafted his deck accordingly. Theres just no way you will win.

Overall I would give this game something like 5-6 out of 10 and im struggling to decide whether to up or down vote here. For now i'll drop a No, but i'll check whats happening with the game in the future and perhaps after changes to the UI i'll upvote this.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In 1 word: Awesome!

I have been playing this game for the last 6 months. The game is very addictive, as the combination of cards is limiteless.
Each time when I think I have seen it all, something new happens.

Be aware that this game is like chess (or like good red wine). You need to play it longer than a day and you will start appreciating  the game.

Some other advantages:
Strong user community
Dedicated fan base
Unlimited amount of fun
Strategic thinking
Hell of a development team

reviewText:
Like a mix between Hearthstone, Yu-Gi-Oh, and that mini card game from Final Fantasy IX, but instead of taking the best parts, they were all placed in a blender and tumbled around a bit, leaving you with this game that drags its feet instead of flying around.



Gameplay: 71/100

Combat Monsters plays on a hexagon style field, like the one Chinese Checkers is played on and like Chinese Checkers, your direction and tactical choices are all around your units/monsters/cards. It's a welcome twist to the general layout the genre, but from there, the focus of the game fades away. It can't seem to decide which aspect should be the backbone of the game, is it a #card game? A monster #fighting game? A chess game? It has a lot of nice ideas, but none of them are the core for everything to be built around. The basics are still that, place a card on the field, move it around strategically based on class: ranged, #melee, #magic, equip weapons and items, cast spells, move on. The simplicity isn't a bad thing, but there's just so much more it can be.


Audio: 77/100

The effects and voices are decent enough, but they're nothing spectacular. If anything, they're almost insulting in the stereotypical #medieval #British voices that are there, as if they were all pre made from some kind of fantasy role playing game library.


Visuals: 74/100

On the #mobile versions, the game is alright. It's not sleek like Hearthstone or high end like some others, it sits somewhere in the middle, but parts here and there makes the PC version seem horrendous. Character faces are just blocky and not even in that nostalgic retro way. The characters themselves are okay, again nothing really standing out that we haven't already seen or some kind of twist that changes the norm.


Content: 73/100
There's a fair amount of things to do, but the game relies on in-game purchases, something that plagues the mobile market and something the developers over at Rubicon seem to want in the Steam version. Granted it isn't shoved down your throat like in the mobile market, but the fact that it is there is a bit of a nuisance for me: Get this pack, buy this item, on and on. And even for little things. One of the first things I tried to do was make my own pendant
date: though it's more a flag than anything, and after a few minutes of customizing it, I was greeted with a prompt that Custom Pendants are for paying customers." Again
recommended: this is something more associated and dealt with in a mobile setting
hoursPlayed:
but a full blow port should have most of these things taken away.


Multiplayer: 72/100

Yes
voteText: there is a multiplayer. Yes
votesHelpful: it was only a few matches. And yes
votesTotal: it's just like the core game from what I can tell
commentsCount: you have a human opponent. It's like a reverse Hearthstone. I know I should stop comparing this small company's game to the massive Hearthstone
column18:
there are bound to be many imitators as time rolls on.


Design: 75/100

Like I stated at the start
column19: the game has some nice ideas
column20: the hexagon field is one of those simple changes that increases the possibilities of the game ten fold
column21: kind of like Tri-Dimensional Chess from Star Trek
column22: but everything else just falls a little flat
column26: disappointing. I was a little excited to play this
column27:
but I couldn't get into it. Maybe it's just me.


Performance: 71/100

Ran fine for the most part. Didn't experience any severe drops in frame rates or tearing. Even the max settings aren't anything to oogle over. I would assume a game like this would look a lot better on a phone or tablet
column28: but on a full computer screen
column29:
it just doesn't hold up.


Verdict: 73/100

I tried to like this game

column34: but it just can't seem to get the ball rolling. Granted the mobile versions seem to have a much warmer reception

column37: but unless more fine tuning is made on the Steam version
column38: it's not something you will keep coming back to over and over again."

reviewText: This game, in all honesty, is not free to play. BUT, if you're willing to drop even 3$ on the Tripler, you can have  alot of fun, and collect cards and a decent pace. I don't feel its slow, or clunky. It has a few areas that need to be ironed out (being asked if I am sure I want to end my turn is annoying...I mean, I DID click it) But it's a fun little game. Think Dungeon Defenders graphics with classic Hex tile combat. Monsters are a little vanilla, but I'm holding out hope it'll get better. It is FREE TO PLAY, and for that amount of money, it's a great game.

reviewText: Edit: This was the top review, with a 'recommended' tag. I've decided I have to change that.\n\nWhile I still really enjoy this game, multiplayer matchmaking is broken beyond belief. People have a very common habit of leaving in the 1st or 2nd turn of a game, for no reason. When they do this, their rating rightfully goes down. But the other person's rating goes UP. This has created a cycle for me where it's basically lose a few matches to players who are way better than me"
date: followed by "winning a bunch of matches in a row because people quit on the 1st turn" which boosts my rank back up to where I'm playing people way better than me. Rinse and repeat.\n\nI reccommend this game for a fun
hoursPlayed: single player experience. Or if you're a pro with a fat wallet. Otherwise I might avoid it

reviewText:
Decent strategy game for a f2p, the mechanics extremely simple and each charecter has its own set of stats and abilities and along with that there's different racial bonuses. There is some depth to it as along with charecter special effects you also have upgrades to runes making you choose between summoning another monster for more board control or gaining permanent bonuses each turn.

Now the main thing that people are probably going to wonder about is the business model. The people saying it takes a week of grind to get a chest are being disingenuous, there's 3 types of chests a 400 1200 and 7200 to buy and each multiplayer game gives about an average of 50 currency. so no it won't take a week to get a chest it'll probably take around an hour, there is however a transaction store, now there's 2 options one to buy game currency and another to buy a permanent multipler.

Now to the people screaming this p2w because you can buy currency well you can do that on virtually every online ccg/tcg so no it isn't those people don't seem to understand what p2w means because you can obtain every thing. There's a crafting system in the game similar to hearthstone's where u can disenchant excess cards for dust to create specific cards, a huge difference from hearthstone which i really hope they change is that you can't disenchant cards in this game unless you've already obtained 4 copies which i hope they change in the future is to allow you to recycle/disenchant regardless of how many copies you have.

Let me be frank this game is not p2w what it might be is a long excessive grind for f2p but it is possible to obtain every card and hero without paying. However so far the game seems fairly fair its 3 dollars for a triple multipler that's permanent while i don't mind paying 3 dollars for it i understand other people who might be hesitant to do so i hope that maybe the booster will be eventually lowered but have the base currency gain from increased as it does seem a bit grindy but there are single player quests that can grant free cards and currency. However there doesn't seem to be any form of daily quests or addictional single player mode post the quest which i hope gets added so there's at least that little perk to logging on each day.

reviewText:
I liked Combat Monsters, I did not play it that long, only a few hours but it seemed like good fun. I should note that I did not experience any pay to win. However as I did not get very far, or anywhere near competitive multiplayer or anything like that, I cannot be certain it doesn't end up pay to win in the end.

The game is part DCG part turn based strategy, and I really liked that. Even with me enjoying the game, you can tell this was, or at least it feels like a mobile port. Not that there is anything really wrong with that, it just comes with its own sets of positive and negatives.   I would recommend this to any free to play nomad" or anyone looking for a decent free DCG/Strategy game.

reviewText:
Very good game in the TCG genre. Swift gameplay with a deep strategic elements both in gameplay and building the deck.

Matches are not to long, around 10 - 20 minutes 1v1.

Playable on PC, android and IOS which make it even better.

Highly recommend to try it out if you like TCG games. If you have not played TCG this is an quite easy game to get into to and explore the TCG genre.

reviewText:
I'm hooked! This really is a great strategy game and combines deck building with turn-based game-play. If chess was invented hundreds of years later then this is what it would look like. With so many  heroes, monsters, weapons and spells etc, the combinations of decks must be endless. I 'm looking forward to getting more cards and get building. The game needs a few tweaks, but hopefully there will be further updates.

It disappoints me to see people leaving negative comments, particularly about the pricing model. Its a free game for crying out loud and you can play the single game without spending any money at all.  Yes, you have to spend a little (or more if you like) to build decks quicker, but I can't see it being anywhere near as expensive some of the other games on here and this looks like its going to entertain me for whole lot longer.

Get involved!
